citations.narrative:
On 4 March 2025 there was a self-reported incident to the IACUC committee involving dairy cattle on an IACUC approved
activity. An animal caretaker noted on 4 March 2025 that 4 dairy cattle were left overnight in the head stanchions after
receiving teat dipping during the 3 March 2025 PM chores and room spray down. The cows were immediately let out of
the head stanchions the morning of 4 March 2025 and were observed with no lameness or cuts, but all went to the waters
to drink. The caretakers did not double-check that the dairy cattle were let out after PM chores resulting in the cows
having been restrained in the head stanchions for approximately 16 hours. Upon further investigation and review of the
room video, all 4 cows tried to get out of the head stanchions on and off until the lights went out at 6:00 PM. In the
morning at 6:00 AM, video showed one cow laying down with the feed bin knocked out of place and 2 other cows laying
down, but no video footage showed the 4th cow laying down. This lack of freedom of movement did not allow the cows to
be able to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as resting with its head pulled back alongside its flank and
a limited ability to groom the back of its body, along with freedom to access the entire primary enclosure and the waterer,
causing the animals distress as demonstrated by their behavior. Ensure that animals requiring short term restraint during
a research activity are released from restraint and provided enough space to allow each animal to make normal postural
and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement. The incident documented above was investigated by the
IACUC. Corrective measures had been implemented prior to inspection, to remain corrected from 8 May 2025 forward.

On 31 December 2024 there was a self-reported incident to the IACUC committee involving pigs on an IACUC approved
activity. On 30 December 2024 during morning checks the caretaker noted that a water line with shut-off valves was
leaking and turned off the water to repair. On 31 December 2024 during morning checks, an animal caretaker noted that
the feed had not been eaten. Checking the waterers, the water valves were turned off. The animal caretaker turned the
water on, and the pigs rushed the waterers, demonstrating by their behavior a lack of water to meet their physiological
needs. The veterinarian was notified and instructed the caretaker to provide additional water sources and electrolytes for
the pigs. The veterinarian noted that the pigs were quiet, with harder fecal output, but responsive and normal otherwise.
Upon further investigation it was discovered that the water valve had been shut off for approximately 19 hours. Lack of
access to water resulted in the 19 pigs not being provided with water as often as necessary to meet their physiological
needs. Ensure potable water is provided in sufficient quantity to pigs housed at the facility, as often as necessary, to
ensure their health and well-being. The incident documented above was investigated by the IACUC. Corrective measures
had been implemented prior to inspection, to remain corrected from 8 May 2025 forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representatives.
End of report.
